title: New Jersey Announces Plans to Replace Notorious and Dangerous Womens Prison
text:
Breaking Local News Report June 13, 2024 Breaking Local News Report June 13, 2024 1 TRENTON, NJ – The New Jersey Department of Corrections (NJDOC) has announced a new phase in the development of a modern women’s correctional facility, to be located in Chesterfield Township, Burlington County. The announcement comes with a call for design and architecture consultation to create a trauma-informed, normative facility that incorporates centralized services and extensive program space.
Commissioner Victoria L. Kuhn, Esq. emphasized the importance of this development, stating that the new facility will meet the modern needs of safety, security, and rehabilitation. The initiative follows Governor Phil Murphy’s 2021 announcement to close the Edna Mahan Correctional Facility and relocate its population to a more central and accessible location, which is projected to save the state approximately $166 million in deferred maintenance and future capital costs.
Assistant Commissioner Helena Tomé highlighted the benefits expected from the new facility, which will foster a rehabilitative and dignified environment conducive to the reintegration of incarcerated women into the community. The facility’s strategic placement on a 33-acre site near major roadways and other correctional institutions aims to enhance family visits, staffing, and access to community resources.
The new correctional facility will share a location with the active Garden State Correctional Facility and is near the recently closed Albert C. Wagner Youth Correctional Facility. It is part of a broader state effort involving multiple agencies, including the Departments of Treasury, Environmental Protection, and Community Affairs.
The NJDOC’s commitment to improving conditions for incarcerated women has been supported by stakeholders like Bonnie Kerness, Program Director of the American Friends Service Committee Prison Watch, who expressed optimism about the positive impact of the new facility on the dignity and rehabilitation of its residents. Man Murdered Inside Brooklyn Subway Station BROOKLYN, NY - A 48-year-old man was pronounced dead following an incident at the Kosciuszko Street Station on Saturday night. Police responded to a 911 call around 10:19 p.m. at the station located within the 81 Precinct/Transit District 33. Upon arrival, officers found Manuel Flores conscious but lying on the floor of the northbound "J" platform.
Emergency Medical Services were promptly called to the scene and transported Flores to NYC Health and Hospitals/Woodhull. He was in stable condition upon arrival but was later pronounced deceased on Sunday.
The Office of Chief Medical Examiner has officially ruled the death a homicide as of Wednesday. Flores lived Brooklyn. Further details about the investigation have not been disclosed at this time.
Gel Gun Drive-Bys Prompt Police Warning in South Jersey GLOUCESTER TOWNSHIP, NJ - Gloucester Township Police have been dealing with a surge of complaints involving juveniles and young adults using "Orbeez Guns" to shoot gel projectiles at people, animals, and properties. An Orbeez gun fires small, colorful, water-absorbing beads.
One notable incident occurred on Gloucester Township Day at Veterans Park, where juveniles reportedly used these guns to target animals. Another significant occurrence involved juveniles firing from a moving vehicle at pedestrians on Tuesday. The suspects, five in total, captured their actions on social media.
Today, Wednesday, at 3 PM, police received additional reports of two males and a female using an Orbeez gun to shoot at unsuspecting pedestrians. This case is currently under investigation.
In response to these events, the Gloucester Township Police Department is urging parents and guardians to discuss the potential dangers of these toy guns with their children. Misidentification of these toys as real guns could pose serious safety risks.
The police are taking a firm stance on this issue, promising to identify, arrest, and charge those misusing the toys to instill fear or cause disturbance among the residents of Gloucester Township.
Arrest Made in Baltimore Homicide Cases BALTIMORE, MD - Following a detailed investigation into the homicides that occurred on June 2, Baltimore detectives have apprehended Munir Dawan Matin, a 36-year-old Baltimore resident, for his alleged involvement in two separate shootings.
Matin is accused of the fatal shooting of 32-year-old Terrell Johnson-Smith on June 2, in the 900 block of Pennsylvania Avenue, and the murder of 34-year-old Jarmal Harrid on the same day, in the 500 block of West Mulberry Street.
The arrest occurred on June 10, when the Warrant Apprehension Task Force located and detained Matin in the 400 block of Fallsway. He was subsequently transported to the Central Booking Intake Facility, facing two counts of first-degree murder among other charges.
This arrest follows an earlier report of gunshots on June 2 around 5:02 PM, where police were alerted to the 900 block of Pennsylvania Avenue by both gunshots and a ShotSpotter activation. At the scene, they found a male victim, later identified as Johnson-Smith, with multiple gunshot wounds. Despite immediate medical attention, he was pronounced dead at the hospital.
Monessen Couple Arrested for Child Endangerment MONESSEN, PA - A couple from Monessen has been arrested following the discovery of their children living in severely neglected conditions. The Monessen Police, in collaboration with the Westmoreland County District Attorney's Office, charged Jerimiah Roberts and Felicia Dugan with endangering the welfare of children, a felony.
The investigation began on June 10 when police were called to the couple's residence on Park Manor for a welfare check on two small children. Upon arrival, officers spoke with Roberts at the door, who stated that the children were staying at a relative's house and that Dugan was asleep on the couch.
Police subsequently made contact with Dugan, who led them to an upstairs bedroom where the children were found sleeping. The conditions in the bedroom were appalling, with feces and old food on the floor, along with flies and fleas. The two-year-old children appeared to have bite marks on their bodies and faces and were visibly dirty.
A witness informed police that Dugan frequently locked the children in the bedroom to prevent them from roaming around the house.
Following these discoveries, both Roberts and Dugan were arraigned and placed in the Westmoreland County Prison.
Three Arrested in Kent County Drug Bust DOVER, DE - Delaware State Police have arrested three men from Magnolia, Delaware, following a prolonged drug investigation in Kent County. The individuals arrested include 19-year-old Algahgaa Ata, 23-year-old Maddyan Ata, and 52-year-old Khaled Ata, all facing multiple charges related to drug dealing.
The investigation, which began in November 2023, was conducted by the Kent County Drug Unit and Delaware Alcohol and Tobacco Enforcement (DATE). The focus was on three businesses: Ali Baba Smoke Shop and Ali Baba 2 Smoke Shop in Dover, and Liberty Happy Gas Station in Magnolia. These locations were suspected of being involved in large-scale drug distribution.
On June 11, detectives stopped a vehicle driven by M. Ata near Magnolia. A search of his car revealed a loaded handgun, about 17 grams of marijuana, and $5,915 in cash believed to be drug proceeds.
Simultaneously, search warrants were executed at the aforementioned businesses and a residence on Ponderosa Drive in Magnolia. A. Ata and K. Ata were apprehended at the Liberty Happy Gas Station. Searches of the properties resulted in the seizure of approximately 1025.32 grams of marijuana and THC products, two handguns, ammunition, drug paraphernalia, and $158,523 in suspected drug proceeds.
Algahgaa Ata was taken to Troop 3 for processing, charged, arraigned by Justice of the Peace Court 2, and subsequently released on a $2,000 unsecured bond.
